It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, commonly known as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its unique, spurred flowers. The plant is hemiparasitic, meaning it partially relies on host plants for nutrients while still performing photosynthesis. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
